security: Disclosing details of FBI electronic surveillance activities, technical methods, and internal organization—as described in the interview with SA William D. Campbell—could jeopardize sensitive sources and ongoing investigations. Directly quoting: 'information which might divulge the identities of FBI sources; information relating to sensitive methods and techniques; information which might adversely affect ongoing FBI investigations'. Revealing this information would compromise the FBI’s intelligence capabilities.
summary: Memoranda regarding interviews conducted by the Senate Select Committee (SSC) with FBI Special Agent William D. Campbell and former Assistant Director Ivan Conrad concerning FBI investigations, specifically related to Martin Luther King Jr. and electronic surveillance activities.
summary_one_paragraph: These memoranda detail information provided to the Senate Select Committee regarding interviews with FBI personnel: Special Agent William D. Campbell and former Assistant Director Ivan Conrad. Campbell's interview covered his involvement in electronic surveillance of Martin Luther King Jr., including technical installations, monitoring activities, and recollections of instructions from superiors like William Sullivan. Conrad's interview focused on his time as AD of the FBI Laboratory, his knowledge of tape copying and filtering procedures, and his awareness of technical coverage on civil rights matters, though he claimed limited specific knowledge regarding King. The documents summarize key aspects of the interviews, including the FBI’s practices regarding technical support, record-keeping, and coordination between different divisions.
title: Abstract of Information Provided to Select Committees
recipient: Mr. W. R. Wannall, Intelligence Community Staff, The Attorney General, Director, FBI, U. S. SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE
